titleStmt.title: A generall bill of the mortality of the clergy of London; or, a brief martyrology and catalogue of the learned, grave, religious, and painfull ministers of the City of London who have been imprisoned, plundered, and barbarousl[y] used, and deprived of all livelihood for themselve[s] and their families, in the late rebellion, for their constancy in the Protestant religion, established in this kingdom[,] and their loyalty to their King, under that great persecution by the Presbyterians.

titleStmt.title: A generall bill of the mortality of the clergy of London; or, a brief martyrology and catalogue of the learned, grave, religious, and painfull ministers of the City of London who have been imprisoned, plundered, and barbarousl[y] used, and deprived of all livelihood for themselve[s] and their families, in the late rebellion, for their constancy in the Protestant religion, established in this kingdom[,] and their loyalty to their King, under that great persecution by the Presbyterians.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in Jesus College Library, Cambridge University.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Church of England -- History -- Early works to 1800.
London (England) -- History -- 17th century -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2009-08 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2009-09 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: A GENERALL BILL OF THE MORTALITY OF THE Clergy of London; Or, A Brief MARTYROLOGY and CATALOGUE OF THE Learned, Grave, Religious, AND Painfull MINISTERS OF THE CITY of LONDON,

Who have been Impriſoned, Plundered, and Barbarouſl • uſed, and deprived of all Livelihood for themſelve • and their Families, in the late REBELLION, for their conſtancy in the Proteſtant Religion, eſtabliſht in this Kingdom and their Loyalty to their KING, under that Grand Perſecution by the PRESBYTERIANS.
LONDON Printed againſt St. Bartholomew day, 1662.

div.head: A Generall Bill of the Mortality of the Clergy of London, &c.

list.item: THE Cathedrall Church of St. Pauls, the Dean, Reſidentiaries, and other Members of that Church, ſequeſtred, plundred, and turn'd out.
St. Alhallows Wood-ſtreet, Dr. Wats ſequeſtred, plundred, his Wife and Children turn'd out of doors, and himſelf forced to fly.
St. Alhallows Barking, Dr. Lafield purſuyvanted, impriſoned in Ely-houſe, and the ſhips; ſequeſtred and plundred, afterwards forced to fly.
St. Alhallows Lumbard-ſtreet, Mr. Weſton ſequeſtred.
St. Alphage, Dr. Halſie ſhamefully abuſed, his Cap pull'd off, to ſee if he were not a ſhaven Prieſt, voted out, and dead with grief.
St. Andrew Hubbard, Dr. Chambers ſequeſtred.

St. Andrew Underſhaft,
1. Mr. Maſon through vexation forced to reſign.
2. Mr. Prichard after that ſequeſtred.
St. Andrew Wardrobe, Dr. Iſaackson ſequeſtred.
St. Anne Alderſgate, Dr. Clewet ſequeſtred.
St. Auſtins Pariſh, Mr. Ʋdall ſequeſtred, his bed-rid Wife turn'd out of doors, and left in the ſtreets.
St. Bartholomew Exchange, Dr. Grant ſequeſtred.
St. Bennet Fink, Mr. Warfield ſequeſtred.
St. Bennet Grace-Church, Mr. Quelch ſequeſtred.
St. Bennet Pauls-wharſe, Mr. Adams ſequeſtred.
St. Bennet Sherhog, Mr. Morgan dead with grief.
St. Botolph Billinſgate, Mr. King ſequeſtred, and forc'd to fly.
Chriſt-Church, Mr. Finch turn'd out, and dead.
St. Chriſtophers, Mr. Hanſlow forc'd to reſign.
St. Clement Eaſt-Cheap, Mr. Stone ſhamefully abuſed, ſequeſtred, ſent Priſoner to Plimouth, and plundered.
St. Dionys Back-Church, Mr. Humes ſequeſtred, and abuſed.
St. Dunſtans Eaſt, Mr. Childerly revil'd, abus'd, and dead.
St. Edmonds Lombard-ſtreet, Mr. Pagu moleſted, ſilenced, and dead.
St. Ethleborough, Mr. Clark ſequeſtred, impriſoned.
St. Faiths, Dr. Browne ſequeſtred, and dead.
St. Foſters, Mr. Batty ſequeſtred, plundered, forc'd to fly, and dead.
St. Gabriell Frenne-Church, Mr. Cook ſequeſtred.
St. George Botolph lane, Dr. Styles forc'd to reſign.
St. Gregories by St. Pauls, Dr. Styles forc'd to reſign.
St. Hellens, Mr Milward turn'd out and dead.
St. James Dukes-place, Mr. ſequeſtred.

St. James Garlick-Hith,
1. Mr. Freeman plundred, and ſequeſtred.
2. Mr. Anthony his Curate turn'd out.
St. John Baptiſt, Mr. Weemſl • y ſequeſtred.
St. John Zachary, Mr. Edlin ſequeſtred, forc'd to fly, and plundered.

St. Catherine Coleman,
1. Dr. Hill forc'd to reſign:
2. Mr. Kilbuts ſequeſtred
St. Catharine Cree-Church, Mr. Ruſh turn'd out.
St. Laurence Jury, Mr. Crane ſequeſtred.
St. Leonard Faſt-cheap, Mr. Calfe forc'd to give up to Mr. Roborow, Scribe to the Aſſembly.
St. Leonard Foſter lane, Mr. Ward forced to fly, plundred, ſequeſtred, and dead for want of neceſſaries.
St. Margaret Lothbury, Mr. Tabor plundred, impriſoned in the Kings-bench, his Wife and Children turned out of doors at mid-night, and he ſequeſtred.
St. Margaret New-Fiſh ſtreet, Mr. Porry forced to fly, plundred, and ſequeſtred.
St. Margaret Pattons, Mr. Meggs plundred, impriſoned in Ely-Houſe, and ſequeſtred.
St. Mary Ab-Church, Mr. Stone plundred, ſent Priſoner by Sea to Plimouth, and ſequeſtred.
St. Mary Aldermary, Mr. Brown forced to forſake it.
St. Mary le Bow, Mr. Leech ſequeſtred, and dead with grief.
St. Mary Bothaw, Mr. Proctor forced to fly, and ſequeſtred.

St. Mary Hill
1. Dr. Baker ſequeſtred, purſuivanted, and impriſoned.
2 Mr. Woodcock turned out, and forced to fly.
St. Mary Mounthaw, Mr. Thrall ſequeſtred, and ſhamefully abuſed.
St. Mary Somerſet, Mr. Cook ſequeſtred.
St. Mary Wool-Church, Mr. Tireman forced to forſake it
St. Mary Woolnoth, Mr. Sh •••… e moleſted, and vext to death, and denyed a Funerall Sermon to be preached by Dr. Holdſworth, as he deſired.
St. Martins Iron-monger lane, Mr. Sparke ſequeſtred, and plundred.
St. Martins Ludgate, Dr. Jermin ſequeſtred.
St. Martins Orgars, Dr. Walton aſſaulted, ſequeſtred, plundred, forced to fly, Mr. Moſſe his Curate turned out.
St. Martins Outwich, Dr. Pierce ſequeſtred, and dead.
St. Martins Vintry, Dr. Ryves ſequeſtred, plundred, and forc'd to fly.
St. Mathew Friday ſtreet, Mr Cheſtlin violently aſſaulted in his houſe, impriſoned in the Compter, thence ſent to Colcheſter Goal in Eſſex, ſequeſtred, and plundered.
St. Maudlins Milk ſtreet, Mr. Jones ſequeſtred.
St. Maudlins Old-Fiſh ſtreet, Dr. Griffith ſequeſtred, plundred, impri • oned, in Newgate, when being let out, he was forc'd to fly, and ſince impriſoned again in Peter-houſe.
St. Michaell Baſſiſhaw, Dr. Gifford ſequeſtred.

St. Michaell Cornhill,
1. Dr. Brough ſequeſtred, plundered, Wife and Children turn'd out of doors, his Wife dead with grief,
2. Mr. Weld his Curate aſſaulted, beaten in the Church and turn'd out.
St. Michaell Queen Hith, Mr Hill ſequeſtred.
St. Michaell Quern, Mr. Launce ſequeſtred.
St. Michaell Royall, Mr. Proctor ſequeſtred, and forc'd to fly.
St. Mildred Bread ſtreet, Mr. Bradſhaw ſequeſtred,
St. Mildred Poultry, Mr. Maden ſequeſtred, and gone beyond Sea.
St. Nicholas Acons, Mr. Pennet ſequeſtred.
St. Nicholas Cole-abby, Mr. Chibald ſequeſtred.
St. Nicholas Olaves, Dr. Ch • ſhire moleſted, and forc'd to reſign.
St. Olaves Hart ſtreet, Mr. Haines ſequeſtred.
St. Olaves Jewry, Mr. Tuke ſequeſtred, plundered, and impriſoned.
St. Olaves ſilver ſtreet, Dr. Booſie abuſed, and dead with grief.
St. Pancraſſe Soper lane, Mr. Eccop ſequeſtred, plundred, forc'd to fly, Wife and Children turn'd out of doors.
St. Peters Cheap-ſide, Mr. Vocheir ſequeſtred, and dead with grief.
St. Peters Cornhill, Dr. Fairfax ſequeſtred, plundered, impriſoned in Ely-houſe, and the ſhips, his Wife and Children turn'd out of doors.
St. Peters Pauls wharfe, Mr. Marbury ſequeſtred.
St. Peters Poor, Dr. Holdſworth ſequeſtred, plundered, impriſoned in Ely-houſe, then in the Tower.
St. Stephens Walbrook, Dr. Howell through vexation forc'd to fly.
St. Swithins, Mr. Owen ſequeſtred.
St. Thomas Apoſtle, Mr. Cooper ſequeſtred, plundered, ſent Priſoner to Leeds Caſtle in Kent, is dead with grief.
Trinity Pariſh Mr. Harriſon ſequeſtred.

div.p: In the 97. Pariſhes within the Walls, beſides St. Pauls, outed 85, and dead 16.

list.head: Pariſhes without the Walls.
list.item: St. ANdrews Holborn, Dr. Hacket ſequeſtred.
St. Bartholmews Great, Bp. Weſtfield abuſed in the ſtreet, ſequeſtred, forced to fly and is dead.

St. Bartholmew leſſe,
1. Mr. Henſhaw,
2. Mr. Hall:
St. Brides Parriſh, Mr. Palmer ſequeſtred.
St. Bridewell Precinct, Mr. Browne turn'd out.
St. Botolph Alderſgate, Mr. Booth ſequeſtred, and plundered.
St. Botolph Allgate, Dr. Swadlin ſequeſtred, plundred, impriſoned at Gr • ſham Colledge, and Newgate, his Wife and Children turn'd out of doors.
St. Botolph Biſhops gate, Mr. Rogers ſequeſtred.
St. Danſtans Weſt, Dr. Marſh ſequeſtred, and died in remote parts.
St. Georges Southwark, Dr. Hobſon ſequeſtred.

St. Giles Criplegate,
1. Dr. Fuller ſequeſtred, plundered, impriſoned at Ely-houſe.
2. Mr. Hutton his Curate, aſſaulted in the Church and impriſoned.
St. Olaves Southwark, Dr. Turner ſequeſtred, plundred, fetcht up Priſoner with a Troop of Souldiers, and after forced to fly.
St. Sepulchers Pariſh, Mr. Pigot the Lecturer turn'd out.
St. Thomas Southwark, Mr. Spencer ſequeſtred, and impriſoned.

div.p: In the 16 Pariſhes without the Walls, outed 14. dead 2.

list.head: In the 10. out Pariſhes.
list.item: St. CLement Danes, Dr. Dukson ſequeſtred, plundred, and forc'd to fly.
Covent Garden, Mr. Hall ſequeſtred, and forc'd to fly.
St. Gyles in the Fields, Dr. Heywood ſequeſtred, impriſoned in the Compter, Ely-houſe, and the ſhips, forc'd to fly, his Wife and Children turn'd out of doors.
St. Leonard Shoreditch, Mr. Squire ſequeſtred, impriſoned in Greſham Colledge, Newgate, and the Kings Bench, his Wife and Children plundred and turn'd out of doors.
St. Martins in the Fields, Dr. Bray ſequeſtred, impriſoned, plundred, forc'd to fly, and dead in remote parts.
St. Mary White-chappel, Dr. Johnſon ſequeſtred.
St. Magdalen Bermondſey, Dr. Paske ſequeſtred.

Savoy,
1. Dr. Balcanquell ſequeſtred, plundred, forc'd to fly, and dead in remote parts.
2. Mr. Fuller forc'd to fly.

div.p: In the 10. out Pariſhes outed 9. dead 2.

list.head: In the Adjacent Towns.
list.item: THE Dean and all the Prebends of the Abby Church Weſtminſter (but only Mr. Lambert Obaston) ſequeſtred.
St. Margarets Westminster, Dr. Wimberly ſequeſtred.
Lambeth, Dr. Featly ſequeſtred, plundred, impriſoned, and dead a Priſoner.
Newington, Mr. Heath ſequeſtred.
Hackney, Mr. Moor ſequeſtred.
Iſlington, Divers Miniſters turn'd out.
Stepney, Dr. Stamp ſequeſtred, plundred, forc'd to fly.

div.p: In the Adjacent Towns, beſides thoſe of the Abby Church and Iſlington, outed 5. dead 1.

list.item: The total of the Miniſters of London within the Bills of Mortality (beſides St. Pauls and Weſtminster) turn'd out of their livings by ſequeſtration and otherwiſe. 115

Whereof Doctors in Divinity above
And the moſt of them plundred of their goods, and their Wives and Children turn'd out of doors. 40.
Impriſoned in London, and in the ſhips and in the ſeverall Go • les and Caſtles in the Country. 20.
Fled to prevent Impriſonment. 25.
Dead in remote parts, and in priſons with grief. 22.
About 40. Churches void, having no conſtant Miniſter in them.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p: IN this brief Catalogue, you have written as it were in ſhort hand within the compaſſe of a penny, the Tragical and more then barbarous Cruelties, exerciſed upon the true Proteſtant Clergy, as well within as without the Walls and Liberties of London; As they were acted in good earneſt by the Brethren of the Presbytery, who now themſelves cry out ſo much of Perſecution. It is much deſired that ſome Ingenuous Perſons in the ſeverall Counties of this Kingdome, will collect and preſent to the World in larger Characters, a Catalogue likewiſe of thoſe Loyall Ministers, who in each reſpective County, have paſt through the Presbyterian Furnace, which like Nebuchadnezzars Oven, was made ſeven times hotter, then that into which Gods juſtice, and the peeviſhneſſe of their refractory Spirits, hath now caſt their mercileſſe Perſecutors.

q.p: Curſed be their wrath for it was fierce, and their rage for it was cruell; I will divide them in Jacob, and ſcatter them in Iſrael.
